thread.title: Providence Health to run walk-in clinics at Walgreens in NW
thread.title_full: Providence Health to run walk-in clinics at Walgreens in NW | The Seattle Times

author: Ángel González
title: Providence Health to run walk-in clinics at Walgreens in NW
text:
Renton-based Providence Health & Services has teamed up with Walgreens to offer walk-in clinics at up to 25 of the pharmacy giant’s stores in Washington and Oregon.
The move highlights the increasing popularity of these clinics, which offer immediate appointments and deal with minor medical issues, as demand for medical services from formerly uninsured patients surges in the wake of the Affordable Care Act.
Providence, a nonprofit, runs 34 hospitals and 475 clinics in the West, including Swedish Health Services.
Dubbed Providence Express Care or Swedish Express Care at Walgreens stores in the Seattle area, the clinics will be owned and run by Providence. Three clinics are to open in the Seattle region and three in the Portland area early next year.
Most Read Stories Wind-whipped wildfire kills 3 firefighters, injures 4 near Twisp No bodies found in wreckage of Bremerton motel Cascadia fault chatters and pops with little quakes When fire chief called for help, and no one was left State cracks down on fraudulent immigration aid Providence said in a statement that the partnership will seek to link the often temporary care provided by these clinics with other parts of its health-care organization. Health records from the Providence and Swedish systems will connect to the clinics, leading to better coordination of information and better care, the organization said.
The clinics will run on extended hours all days of the week. The first three stores in the Seattle area — in Kirkland, Renton and Issaquah — will be staffed by Swedish practitioners. Providence staffers will operate stores in Vancouver, Wash., and in Beaverton and Milwaukie, Ore.
Providence and Walgreens said that their partnership will explore opportunities of further collaboration across the Deerfield, Ill.-based retailer’s national footprint.
The deal follows a similar move by local pharmacy chain Bartell Drugs, which in 2013 joined forces with Group Health to provide walk-in clinics at its stores. The clinics, dubbed CareClinics, are at Bartells in North Seattle, Ballard and Bellevue.
Rite Aid, the Camp Hill, Pa.-based pharmacy chain, in May announced that its retail clinic unit and MultiCare Health System, a regional nonprofit health provider, would join forces to open 11 clinics in Seattle-area Rite Aid pharmacies.
Ángel González: 206-464-2250 or agonzalez@seattletimes.com . On Twitter @gonzalezseattle
